Actinacidiphila paucisporea is a species of actinobacteria that was isolated from acidic soil samples. The following is a brief scientific description of this species:

Actinacidiphila paucisporea is a Gram-positive, aerobic, non-spore-forming, rod-shaped bacterium. It is acidophilic, capable of growing optimally at pH values around 4-5. The cells are approximately 0.5-0.8 μm wide and 1.0-2.5 μm long. 

The colonies of A. paucisporea appear pale-yellow to orange in color on agar media. The cells are capable of producing a limited number of spores, typically less than 10 per cell, which accounts for the species epithet "paucisporea" meaning "few-spored".

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences has placed A. paucisporea within the family Sporichthyaceae, order Frankiales, class Actinobacteria. It is most closely related to other acidophilic actinobacterial genera such as Acidimicrobium and Ferrimicrobium.

A. paucisporea is considered an acidophilic specialist, adapted to thrive in low pH environments. It is believed to play a role in the cycling of nutrients and organic matter in acidic soil ecosystems.
